text: Hi, this is Kate from MinuteEarth.
And my dog Watson looks like this.
But there are also dogs that look like this.
And this.
And this and this and this.

They’re so different that they barely seem
like the same species.

While there are some definite weirdos in the
feline world, cats generally look - and act
- much more similar to each other than dogs.

So yeah, doggos are way more diverse than
cattos...except they also aren’t.

Because under all those superficial differences
- what scientists call “phenotypic diversity”

- domestic dogs are surprisingly un-diverse
in the DNA department.

On average, only a tiny fraction of dogs’
DNA differs from each other - that’s about

as much as their owners, and several times
less than cats generally differ genetically
from each other.

So why do dogs look and act so doggone distinctive,
compared to humans or cats?

Well, because it matters how genetic differences
are distributed within a species.

Instead of genetic differences, let’s look
at colored dots.

Say you have a bunch of dots - equal numbers
of four different colors.
Now divide those dots up into four groups.

Within each group, you could have all the
colors represented - each of these smaller

groups, then, would include all the diversity
that exists among the dots as a whole.

Alternatively, each group could consist of
dots of just one color - in this scenario,

all the individuals in each group are really
similar to each other, but they’re really
different from individuals in the other groups.

This is kind of like what we’ve done with
dogs.

Over centuries of careful breeding, we’ve
partitioned different genes and variants of
genes into different groups of dogs.

As a result, dogs in different groups - which
we call “breeds” - are genetically really

similar to each other, and really different
from dogs of other breeds.

That’s how - even without a ton of genetic
variation - we’ve ended up with dogs with

such distinct characteristics: think stubby
legs in weiner dogs versus ridiculous stilts
in greyhounds.

Compared to dogs, cats have more genetic diversity
overall, but since we haven’t been breeding

cats as long or as carefully, their cat-egories
are less well-defined.

Each breed still contains a lot of the genetic
diversity that exists in the species as a

whole, so cats within a breed aren’t all
that genetically similar - and cats of different
breeds ARE somewhat similar.
And as for us humans?

Well, people within any one “population”
of humans don’t have much more in common

genetically than they do with people from
other populations.

On top of all this, for reasons we don’t
exactly understand, a few spots in the dog
genome have outsize effects on a dog’s outside.

As far as we can tell, variation in just 14
genes causes almost all the variation in dogs’

size - compare that to the several hundred
genes that contribute to humans’ height
and BMI.

So it’s pretty straightforward to create
dogs with a forty-fold size difference.

But dogs aren’t total outliers - we’ve
bred chickens with a 15-fold size difference

and turned a humble plant called Brassica
oleracea into a diverse - and delicious - plethora
of forms.

So even though cats today all seem pretty
similar, given another hundred years of careful

selection, we could probably breed cats that
vary as much as dogs.

But first, we might want to consider whether
breeding giant cats might be a giant cat-astrophe.

Hey, you cool cats - we love it when you stick
around to the end!

support our work and you’re feel-ine generous,
